column1: The Sea-kings knew this harbor and rowed straight into it and ran their ship half a keel's length ashore. Then they lifted Ulysses out of the stern
column2: wrapt in the rugs and coverlet
column3: and laid him still asleep upon the sand. And the gifts they placed in a heap by the trunk of the olive-tree
column4: a little out of the road
column5: so that no passer-by might rob him as he slept.Then they sailed away; and after they were gone Ulysses awoke
column6: but he could not recognize the land where he lay
column7: for Athene had cast a mist about him so that everything looked strange
column8: though he was the lord of it all. There were the mountain paths and the sheltering creeks
column10: steep rocks and the trees in bloom; but he could not see it aright
column11: and started up and smote his hands upon his thighs and cried aloud
column12: —"What land have I come to now? And what can I do with all this treasure?
